title: Illinois sues the Trump administration over National Guard deployment to Chicago
summary: Illinois filed a lawsuit Monday in an attempt to block the Trump administration from deploying federalized National Guard troops on the streets of Chicago.
story: Illinois filed a lawsuit Monday in an attempt to block the Trump administration from deploying federalized National Guard troops on the streets of Chicago.

“The American people, regardless of where they reside, should not live under the threat of occupation by the United States military, particularly not simply because their city or state leadership has fallen out of a president’s favor,” the Illinois attorney general's office wrote in the filing, which names President Donald Trump, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Army Secretary Daniel Driscoll as defendants.
“The Trump administration’s illegal actions already have subjected and are subjecting Illinois to serious and irreparable harm,” the suit says.
The White House maintained Trump's actions are lawful.

“Amidst ongoing violent riots and lawlessness, that local leaders like [Illinois Gov. JB] Pritzker have refused to step in to quell, President Trump has exercised his lawful authority to protect federal officers and assets. President Trump will not turn a blind eye to the lawlessness plaguing American cities,” said White House spokeswoman Abigail Jackson.
Representatives for the Justice Department, U.S. Army and Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to request for comment. The Pentagon declined to comment.

The legal action comes after a federal judge in Oregon issued two separate orders over the weekend temporarily blocking the Trump administration from sending federalized National Guard members from California — or any other state — to Portland, Oregon. Portland and Chicago are part of a wave of Democrat-run cities and states that Trump has targeted with federal troops.

“This country has a longstanding and foundational tradition of resistance to government overreach, especially in the form of military intrusion into civil affairs,” U.S. District Judge Karin Immergut, a Trump appointee, wrote in one of her rulings.
The suit brought on behalf of Illinois and the city of Chicago makes similar arguments about federal overreach.

“The Federalization Order’s deployment of federalized military forces to protect federal personal and property from 'violent demonstrations' that 'are occurring or are likely to occur' represents the exact type of intrusion on State power that is at the heart of the Tenth Amendment," the suit says.

“The deployment of federalized National Guard, including from another state, infringes on Illinois’s sovereignty and right to self-governance. It will cause only more unrest, including harming social fabric and community relations and increasing the mistrust of police. It also creates economic harm, depressing business activities and tourism that not only hurt Illinoisians but also hurt Illinois’s tax revenue,” the suit says.

The city and the state want a judge to declare the administration’s federalization and deployment of the National Guard of the United States, any state National Guard, or deployment of the U.S. military in Illinois as "unconstitutional and/or unlawful."
Trump had been threatening to send the National Guard into Chicago for months, and gave the green light to do so over the weekend.

“Amidst ongoing violent riots and lawlessness, that local leaders like [Illinois Gov. JB] Pritzker have refused to step in to quell, President Trump has authorized 300 national guardsmen to protect federal officers and assets,” White House spokeswoman Abigail Jackson said in a statement.
The suit denies there's any emergency in the city or that there's a need for federal troops.

"The supposed current emergency is belied by the fact that Trump’s Chicago troop deployment threats began more than ten years ago," the suit says, pointing to a 2013 Trump tweet where he wrote, "we need our troops on the streets of Chicago, not in Syria.”

He's since worked to "demonize cities where Democrats had been elected as leaders," and provoked unrest in the state by surging federal law enforcement to target undocumented immigrants and protesters outside of an immigration detention facility in the suburb of Broadview, the suit says.

"Among other things, Trump and Noem have sent a surge of SWAT-tactic trained federal agents to Illinois to use unprecedented, brute force tactics for civil immigration enforcement; federal agents have repeatedly shot chemical munitions at groups that included media and legal observers outside the Broadview facility; and dozens of masked, armed federal agents have paraded through downtown Chicago in a show of force and control," the suit says.
"The community’s horror at these tactics and their significant consequences have resulted in entirely foreseeable protests," it added.
Pritzker, in an interview Sunday on CNN’s “State of the Union,” said federal authorities “are the ones that are making it a war zone" in Chicago.
Trump has threatened to send the National Guard into other prominent Democratic-run cities against their wishes as well, including New York, Baltimore and New Orleans.

The warning comes as the rate of serious crimes has dropped dramatically in those cities and in Chicago in recent years. Statistics from the Chicago Police Department show the murder rate through the end of September is down 29% compared to the  same time period last year. Overall crime is down 13%, according to CPD.

Trump previously deployed National Guard troops to Los Angeles and Washington, D.C. In early September, a federal judge in California ruled that Trump’s deployment of Marines and National Guard members there was illegal. D.C.'s Democratic attorney general has also sued to challenge the deployment of troops in the capital.

title: Federal judge pauses Trump's deployment of National Guard to Portland
summary: California Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sunday said that he would sue the Trump administration after they deployed 300 California National Guard troops to Oregon.
story: A federal judge in Oregon has blocked the Trump administration from sending federalized National Guard members from California — or any other state — to the streets of Portland, Oregon.

In a rare, late Sunday night virtual hearing, U.S. District Judge Karin Immergut granted the motion for a temporary restraining order filed by the state of California, which asked her to prevent the deployment of up to 300 members of the California National Guard to Portland.
The decision from Immergut, a Trump appointee, came a day after she blocked President Donald Trump’s attempt to deploy Oregon National Guard troops in Portland.

Earlier Sunday, California Gov. Gavin Newsom said he would sue the Trump administration after it deployed the federalized troops — National Guard members called into service by the president — to Oregon.

“This is a breathtaking abuse of the law and power,” Newsom said in a statement. “The Trump Administration is unapologetically attacking the rule of law itself and putting into action their dangerous words — ignoring court orders and treating judges, even those appointed by the President himself, as political opponents.”
In a statement, the White House had confirmed the movement of California National Guard troops to Oregon.

“President Trump exercised his lawful authority to protect federal assets and personnel in Portland following violent riots and attacks on law enforcement,” White House spokesperson Abigail Jackson said.

Chief Pentagon spokesman Sean Parnell said in a statement Sunday that members of the California National Guard were being reassigned from the Los Angeles area to Portland “to support U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and other federal personnel performing official duties, including the enforcement of federal law, and to protect federal property.”
Oregon Gov. Tina Kotek, a Democrat, confirmed that some of the troops had flown into Oregon on Saturday night and said “it is our understanding that there are more on the way today.”

She condemned the move, saying in a statement: “The facts haven’t changed. There is no need for military intervention in Oregon. There is no insurrection in Portland. No threat to national security. Oregon is our home, not a military target. Oregonians exercising their freedom of speech against unlawful actions by the Trump Administration should do so peacefully.”
Texas National Guard called into service

Before the late-night ruling, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said in a memo Sunday that he is calling up to 400 members of the Texas National Guard into federal service in Chicago and Portland for up to 60 days with the potential for an extension.

“On October 4, 2025, the President determined that violent incidents, as well as the credible threat of continued violence, are impeding the execution of the laws of the United States in Illinois, Oregon, and other locations throughout the United States,” Hegseth wrote.
The memo was included in a court filing by the Oregon attorney general’s office in the Oregon National Guard case Sunday night.
Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker said in a news release Sunday that no federal officials had called him to coordinate the guard's deployment.

“We must now start calling this what it is: Trump’s Invasion," wrote Pritzker, a Democrat. "It started with federal agents, it will soon include deploying federalized members of the Illinois National Guard against our wishes, and it will now involve sending in another state’s military troops.”
Pritzker and Kotek called on Texas Gov. Greg Abbott to withdraw any support for that decision.
Abbott, a Republican, said on X that he "fully authorized the President to call up 400 members of the Texas National Guard to ensure safety for federal officials."

"You can either fully enforce protection for federal employees or get out of the way and let Texas Guard do it," Abbott said. "No Guard can match the training, skill, and expertise of the Texas National Guard."
The White House and Abbott’s office did not immediately respond to requests for comment about the Texas guard's deployment to Illinois.
Kotek blasted the Texas news Sunday night, saying she had received no "direct explanation" from Trump or Hegseth about why the action was needed and refused to coordinate.
“This is a continuation and escalation of the President’s dangerous, un-American misuse of states’ National Guard members and hard-earned taxpayer dollars," Kotek wrote.
Temporary restraining order

California Attorney General Rob Bonta celebrated Immergut’s decision Sunday to block the deployment of California Guard troops to Oregon, and implied that the Trump administration's attempt to move the troops was in response to the federal judge's order the day before.

“The Trump Administration’s flagrant disregard for the courts was on full display when it sought to circumvent Judge Immergut’s order blocking the federalization of the Oregon National Guard by redeploying troops from Los Angeles to Portland,” Bonta said in a statement late Sunday. “This disrespect for the rule of law cannot stand—and I’m glad the court agreed."
Immergut on Saturday temporarily blocked the administration's activation of 200 Oregon National Guard troops to Portland until at least Oct. 18.
“This country has a longstanding and foundational tradition of resistance to government overreach, especially in the form of military intrusion into civil affairs,” she wrote in her ruling.
In response, the Trump administration filed a motion with the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for an emergency pause of the decision.
The Trump administration said Immergut “impermissibly second-guessed” Trump’s military judgments.
“Nearly 200 years ago, the Supreme Court made clear that these judgment calls are for the President to make — not a Governor, and certainly not a federal court,” the motion read.

In a statement after Saturday's ruling, Kotek said: “There is no insurrection in Portland. No threat to national security. No fires, no bombs, no fatalities due to civil unrest. The only threat we face is to our democracy — and it is being led by President Donald Trump.”

In an op-ed published Sunday in The Oregonian, Portland Police Chief Bob Day didn't denounce Trump's deployment of the National Guard outright, but he said "national portrayals" of Portland were overstating the problem there.

"There is no ignoring that we are facing an extraordinary time in our city’s history, with the deployment of both federal law enforcement and the Oregon National Guard," Day wrote. "One of the reasons given for this action has been that Portland Police are not responding to public disorder."

"Just because officers are not seen wearing tactical gear lining up before crowds does not mean we are not responding. In fact, research shows that such tactics often escalate crowd behavior. Instead, we use a layered approach when it comes to managing public order," he added.
Trump clashes with Democratic leaders
Trump clashed repeatedly with Democratic governors and mayors over the weekend over his moves to deploy National Guard troops across the country.
In addition to the lawsuit from Democratic leaders in Portland and Oregon, Pritzker blasted Trump's decision Saturday to deploy National Guard troops in Chicago, an idea Trump has floated for weeks.
“It is absolutely outrageous and un-American to demand a Governor send military troops within our own borders and against our will,” Pritzker said in a statement Saturday.

In an interview Sunday on CNN's “State of the Union,” Pritzker said federal authorities "are the ones that are making it a war zone. They need to get out of Chicago if they're not going to focus on the worst of the worst, which is what the president said they were going to do. They need to get the heck out."
Democrats also blasted Trump's comments to senior military leaders last week that the military should "use some of these dangerous cities as training grounds for our military National Guard."
Before the Trump administration's moves this weekend in Portland and Chicago, it had deployed National Guard troops to two other cities, Los Angeles and Washington.
Trump has also threatened to deploy troops and federal law enforcement to other cities, including Baltimore and New Orleans.

In Los Angeles last month, a federal judge ruled that the deployment of National Guard troops and Marines was illegal. Days later, officials in Washington also sued to block the deployment of National Guard troops in the nation's capital.

title: Paramount acquires Bari Weiss' The Free Press, naming her the top editor of CBS News
summary: The newly formed media corporation Paramount Skydance has acquired The Free Press, an online news and commentary outlet co-founded by Bari Weiss, who will join CBS News as editor-in-chief
story: The newly formed media corporation Paramount Skydance has acquired The Free Press, an online news and commentary outlet co-founded by Bari Weiss, who will join CBS News as editor-in-chief.

Weiss launched The Free Press in 2021 with her wife, Nellie Bowles, and her sister, Suzy Weiss. They have presented the publication as a heterodox alternative to the legacy news media and a bulwark against “ideological narratives,” particularly on the political left.
The acquisition is one of Skydance chief David Ellison’s most significant early moves to reshape the news unit at Paramount, which he acquired in a blockbuster $8 billion deal earlier this year.

In seeking federal approval of the merger, Skydance vowed to embrace “diverse viewpoints” and represent “the varied ideological perspectives of American viewers.” The company also pledged to install an ombudsman at the nearly 100-year-old CBS News operation.

“This partnership allows our ethos of fearless, independent journalism to reach an enormous, diverse, and influential audience,” Weiss said in a news release. “We honor the extraordinary legacy of CBS News by committing ourselves to a singular mission: building the most trusted news organization of the 21st Century.”

The Free Press has roughly 1.5 million subscribers on Substack, with more than 170,000 of them paid, according to Paramount Skydance. The Financial Times estimated that the publication generates more than $15 million in annual subscription revenue. NBC News has not independently verified that figure.

“Bari is a proven champion of independent, principled journalism, and I am confident her entrepreneurial drive and editorial vision will invigorate CBS News,” Ellison said in a statement. “This move is part of Paramount’s bigger vision to modernize content and the way it connects — directly and passionately — to audiences around the world.”

The acquisition talks between Ellison and Weiss were first reported in late June by Status, a media industry newsletter. Ellison is the son of billionaire tech mogul Larry Ellison, the co-founder of the software firm Oracle.

Weiss co-founded The Free Press after quitting the opinion section of The New York Times. In a resignation letter that was published online, Weiss decried what she characterized as the “illiberal environment” at the newspaper.

The Free Press earned wide attention in April 2024 after it published an essay from Uri Berliner, a senior business editor at National Public Radio who accused his employer of organizing around a “progressive worldview.” Berliner then resigned from NPR and joined The Free Press.

The publication’s regular stable of columnists includes Tyler Cowen, an economist and podcaster; Matthew Continetti, the author of a book about the evolution of American conservatism; and Niall Ferguson, a British-American historian.

CBS News has repeatedly found itself in the national spotlight in recent months. President Donald Trump filed a lawsuit last year against Paramount accusing “60 Minutes” of deceptively editing an interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris.
CBS denied the claim. Paramount settled Trump’s lawsuit for $16 million.

The Federal Communications Commission is still investigating whether CBS engaged in “news distortion.” The commission is chaired by Brendan Carr, who was appointed by Trump at the start of his second term.

title: Taylor Swift says theories that 'Showgirl' will be her last album are 'offensive'
summary: The life of a showgirl is, and always will be, for Taylor Swift.
story: The life of a showgirl is, and always will be, for Taylor Swift.

Days after her latest album release, Swift addressed what she called an "offensive" fan rumor that implied she would be done recording and releasing new music after her impending nuptials to Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce.
The pair's August engagement announcement followed closely behind Swift's reveal on Kelce's "New Heights" podcast that her 12th studio album, "The Life of a Showgirl," would be released on Oct. 3.
As part of the album’s promotion, Swift spoke with BBC Radio 2  in an interview that aired on Monday, during which Scott Mills asked her about the rumors.
"Taylor, don't tell me this is your last album," Mills asked.

The "Opalite" singer immediately looked confused, shaking her head. He clarified that he has seen fans discussing the possibility of the end of Swift's music career, citing her upcoming marriage and a future that could include children.
"That's a shockingly offensive thing to say," Swift responded. "That's not why people get married, so that they can quit their job."

Mills clarified that he thinks "the fans were just panicking," implying that the rumors actually came from a good place, and that Swifties were just fearful this would be the end of the music they know and love.
"They love to panic sometimes," Swift admitted.
But slowing down after marriage is not in Swift's cards, namely because she said her fiancé supports her career.

"I love the person that I am with because he loves what I do and he loves how much I am fulfilled by making art and making music," Swift said. She added that one of the "coolest" things about him is that he, too, is "so passionate about what he does that me being passionate about what I do — it connects us."

"There's no point in time where he's going to be like, 'I'm really upset that you're still making music. The music thing that I signed up for, that I knew you love, I thought you were gonna stop doing that,'" Swift continued.
She said that it's the "most fun thing in the world" that she and Kelce can support each other in each of their larger-than-life careers, and noted the differences and similarities of what they do.

"We both, as a living, as a job, as a passion, perform for three-and-a-half hours in NFL stadiums ... to entertain people," Swift said. "When I'm in those stadiums, it's a dressing room. But when he's in those exact same stadiums, it's a locker room. For him, it's practice. For me, it's rehearsal. For him, it's a game. For me, it's a show," Swift said.
Even though they "call them different things," both stars are surrounded by teams, making their careers "a very similar thing," Swift said.
She added that they're both competitive "in fun ways, not in ways that eat away at us, but just like, we just love it."

Swift will continue her media tour for "Showgirl," which has already broken records, with an appearance Monday on "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon." Later this week, she will also join "Late Night with Seth Meyers."

Fans have speculated she'll keep the NBC appearances alive with a surprise spot on "Saturday Night Live" when Sabrina Carpenter — who is featured on the album's title track and a friend of Swift's — performs double duty on Oct. 18.
A representative for Swift did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the interview.

title: 51 actually good early October Prime Day deals
summary: You don’t have to wait until October 7 to save — here are the top early Prime Day discounts live today from Apple, Shark, Kindle, CeraVe and more.
story: Amazon’s October Prime Day, Prime Big Deal Days, officially starts tomorrow — this year it runs from Oct. 7 to 8, and, like years’ past, it’s exclusive to Prime members. But that doesn’t mean you should wait to shop. The retailer is already offering hundreds of deals from some of our favorite brands, and if you check out soon, you’ll get the exact size, style or model you’re looking for. That's especially important if you’re starting to buy gifts for loved ones.

I've covered Prime Day at NBC Select for over five years, so I know how to find deals that are actually worth buying. I combed through thousands of discounts to find the best early October Prime Day deals — each one I recommend below is highly rated and 20% off or more, as well as at its lowest price in at least three months or lowest price ever. Shark Lift-Away Upright Vacuum (ZD201)

This corded upright vacuum, which is suitable for all floor types, has a detachable pod you can tote around your home to clean above doorframes, under furniture, on top of upholstery and on stairs. Its HEPA filter traps dust and other allergens while it suctions up debris, and its LED headlights illuminate dirt so you don’t miss spots. The vacuum comes with crevice and upholstery tools.
Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition Essentials Bundle

You get a Kindle Paperwhite, fabric cover and wireless charging dock with this bundle, covering all your essentials if you’re getting your first e-reader or upgrading. The Paperwhite has a 7-inch glare-free screen and a 12-week battery life, according to the brand, plus its front light automatically adjusts to whatever environment you’re in. It’s also water-resistant, so you can read at the beach, pool or in the bath. The cover that’s included with this bundle attaches to your e-reader, waking it up or putting it to sleep as you open and close it like a book.
Oral-B iO Deep Clean Rechargeable Electric Powered Toothbrush

Oral-B’s electric toothbrush has all the features dentists told me to look for while shopping: a pressure sensor, a built-in timer, multiple cleaning settings and a brush head change alert. The rechargeable toothbrush comes with two replacement brush heads and a travel case.
Ring Battery Doorbell Plus

See, hear and speak to visitors with this video doorbell. It pairs with Ring’s app, which shows you HD livestream footage (including in color night vision) and sends you alerts when the device detects people, packages or motion. The doorbell is powered by a removable, rechargeable battery, so there’s no electrical work required for setup, and it comes with mounting tools, too.
CeraVe Skin Renewing Vitamin C Eye Cream

CeraVe’s fragrance-free eye cream is made with vitamin C to brighten dark under eyes and caffeine to reduce puffiness, plus hyaluronic acid and ceramides to moisturize skin, according to the brand. It has a lightweight, non-sticky, non-greasy feel that quickly absorbs into skin, and is safe for those who wear contacts, according to Cerave. The brand recommends using it twice daily.
Ecolution Micro-Pop Microwave Popcorn Popper

Ecolution’s Micro-Pop is one of my favorite kitchen gadgets because it helps me make fresh, warm popcorn in minutes (trust me, it’s way better than the store-bought stuff). You add kernels to the built-in measuring cup on the lid, pour them into the bowl and place it in the microwave for about three minutes. You can also put butter on top of the lid, which has holes in it;  as the butter melts in the microwave, it drips onto the popcorn. The 3-quart, dishwasher-safe popper has a wide opening, so once it cools down, it doubles as a serving bowl.
Amazon Fire TV Stick HD

Stream your favorite shows, movies, music and more from any TV when you plug this Fire Stick into an HDMI port. It comes with an Alexa Voice Remote, letting you adjust settings via voice commands, and it displays pictures in vibrant HD. You can also use the Fire Stick to control compatible smart home devices like thermostats, cameras and lights.
Amazon Smart Plug

Plug devices like fans, air purifiers and small kitchen appliances into this smart plug to control them via the Amazon Alexa app or voice commands.  The app also lets you set up schedules, timers and routines for your devices.  The plug is compact, so it won’t block your second outlet.
Neutrogena Hydro Boost Body Lotion

Neutrogena's lightweight, fragrance-free body lotion hydrates skin using ingredients like hyaluronic acid, and it absorbs quickly without leaving behind a greasy or oily residue. It's also safe for sensitive-skin, according to the brand.
Rubbermaid Brilliance Food Storage Containers

Meal prep and store leftovers in these dishwasher- and microwave-safe containers, each of which have a 3.2-cup capacity and come with leak-proof lids. The lids also have built-in vents so you don't have to remove them while microwaving food. Since the containers, which come in a pack of five, are clear, you can always see what's inside. Plus, they're stackable, helping you save space in your kitchen.
Batiste Original Dry Shampoo (3 pack)

Don't worry about running out of dry shampoo when you buy this pack of three bottles — you can use one now and save the others for later, or keep one at home and put the others in your toiletry bag. Batiste's Original formula is made with keratin, and it absorbs oil and grease at your roots to leave your hair looking and feeling clean between washes. It also adds volume. The dry shampoo is scented with orange, lily and rose.
Shark Wandvac WV200 Series Handheld Vacuum

Keep this handheld vacuum on hand at home for small messes, or use it to clean your car. It's lightweight at only 1.4 pounds, and it comes with a charging dock, duster crevice tool and multi-surface pet hair tool. You empty the Wandvac by holding it over a trash can and pressing a button, which pops the dustbin open to discards debris.
Magna-Tiles Dino World 40-Piece Magnetic Construction Set

"Magna-Tiles are without a doubt the number one toy students fought over at school when I was a pre-school teacher," says NBC Select editorial projects manager Rebecca Rodriguez. This set comes with 40 multi-colored pieces, including four dinosaur figurines. The pieces are compatible with Magna-Tiles from other sets, too.
Amazon Echo Pop

This Bluetooth speaker may be small, but it’s loud enough to fill a room with sound whether you’re listening to music, a podcast or an audiobook. It has Amazon Alexa built-in, so you can use voice commands to ask questions, set timers and reminders, control compatible smart home devices and more. I keep my Echo Pop in my bedroom and ask Alexa about the weather while I’m getting dressed every day. The device has volume control buttons, as well as a button to turn the microphone off.
Belif Vitamin E Jelly Overnight Mask

Dry skin season is upon us now that the temperatures are dropping, so adding more hydrating products to your routine might be beneficial. This lightweight, no-rinse mask creates a barrier over your skin to lock in moisture overnight. It’s made with ingredients like hyaluronic acid and niacinamide, which leave your skin feeling smoother and looking more plump after use, according to the brand.
Amazon Blink Mini 2

The Blink Mini 2 is one of my favorite security cameras because it’s so small — it blends into my space instead of being an eyesore. You can use it indoors and outdoors, and it connects to the Blink app, where you can livestream HD footage, hear audio and speak to people and pets. The camera also has a built-in spotlight, and you can use it as a plug-in chime with Blink Video Doorbells (which are also currently on sale). The app sends you motion detection alerts, too.
Brita Elite Filtered Water Pitcher

The filter inside Brita's 10-cup pitcher removes contaminants like lead, chlorine, microplastics and mercury from your drinking water, according to the brand. One filter lasts about six months, and there's an alert light on the pitcher's lid to help you keep track of when you need to replace it. The pitcher  fits in most refrigerators and has a wide opening, making it easy to fill.
Blueair 311i Max Air Purifier

Air purifiers like this one can remove tiny airborne particles from your home, like allergens, dust, smoke, bacteria and pet hair. The Blueair 311i connects to WiFi and pairs with the brand’s app, letting you adjust its mode (auto or night), fan speed, brightness and child lock setting, as well as track filter usage, air quality and more. The appliance is best for medium rooms and it responds to voice commands, too.

title: Jason Kelce Can’t Resist Asking Travis About His Wedding in New Interview
summary: Jason Kelce is asking brother Travis Kelce the most important question that Swifties are dying to know
story: Jason Kelce is asking brother Travis Kelce the most important question that Swifties are dying to know.

Ahead of the Monday Night Football matchup between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Jacksonville Jaguars on Oct. 6, the brothers "New Heights" podcast teased its upcoming interview that Jason Kelce is conducting with Travis Kelce, as well as Patrick Mahomes and Andy Reid, on social media.

During the sit-down, which will air on ESPN’s “Monday Night Countdown!” starting at 6 p.m. ET, Jason Kelce chats with the trio about how the team’s season is going so far. But before he talks about sports, he has a personal question to ask his brother.
In a snippet from the interview posted on social media,  Jason Kelce breaks the ice by playfully inquiring about Travis Kelce’s wedding plans with Taylor Swift now that the two are engaged.
“Let’s start with what everybody wants to know. Trav, when’s the wedding?” Jason Kelce asks.
“Shut the f– up,” Travis Kelce replies as he and Mahomes start laughing.
“This guy,” Travis Kelce says. “I was wondering what he was going to ask.”
“I didn’t know what was coming next,” Mahomes adds.
Unfortunately for Swifties, Travis Kelce didn’t share any details about the couple’s upcoming nuptials in the clip.
Travis Kelce has been somewhat tight-lipped about the wedding since he and Swift announced their engagement on Instagram Aug. 26.
“Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married,” the pop icon captioned the post, which included a series of engagement photos.
In an interview with Fox Sports’ Erin Andrews that aired Sept. 14, Travis Kelce did reveal some details about the proposal and how it felt popping the question.
“The palms were definitely sweating,” he recalled. “I’m an emotional guy, so there were a few tears here and there.”
He continued, “It’s been an exciting ride up until this day, and I can’t wait to spend the rest of my life with her.”
Travis Kelce then praised his fiancée for bringing “excitement and a joy for life that made me a better man, made me a better person and made me just that much more comfortable in who I am.”

title: The 15 Most Banned Books in US Schools
summary: The most commonly banned books in U.S. schools include Sarah J. Maas, Judy Blume, "A Clockwork Orange" and more, according to a new report.
story: The most commonly banned books in U.S. schools include LGBTQ titles, international bestsellers, teen romantasy novels and a 1962 classic, according to a new report that compares modern-day censorship to Cold War-era McCarthyism.

More than 6,800 book bans were enacted during the 2024-25 school year in 87 public school districts across 23 states, according to a report released Wednesday by PEN America, a nonprofit that advocates for free expression. The report was released ahead of Banned Books Week, which starts Sunday.

“Censorship pressures have expanded and escalated,” Kasey Meehan, director of PEN America’s Freedom to Read program, said in a news release. “A disturbing ‘everyday banning’ and normalization of censorship has worsened and spread over the last four years.”

title: Taylor Swift Reveals What Her Mom Thinks ‘Wood’ Is Really About
summary: Taylor Swift shares that her mom missed the double meaning in “Wood,” one of her new songs about Travis Kelce.
story: Taylor Swift may be celebrating her fiancé Travis Kelce's sexual bravado on her new song "Wood," but her mom, Andrea Swift, seems blissfully unaware.
"I think that she thinks that that song is about superstitions, popular superstitions — which it absolutely is," Swift said of her mom during an interview on SiriusXM’s "The Morning Mash Up."

While "Wood," off Swift's new album "The Life of a Showgirl," does indeed contain references to superstitious activities — like "knocking on wood" and "stepping on cracks" — Swift also playfully celebrates Travis Kelce’s anatomy on the track.
The song’s lyrics mention “redwood” trees and “new heights of manhood” while also crediting Kelce’s “magic wand" for breaking a “curse” she'd been under.
More blatantly, Swift sings of Kelce’s “love” being the “key that opened (her) thighs.”

“That’s the joy of the double entendre," Swift said of the song’s blush-worthy metaphors. "That song, you could read that song for people and it just goes right over their head. You see in that song what you wanna see in that song.”
Swift sings joyfully about her love affair with Kelce, which began more than two years ago, on several other songs on the new album, including "Opalite."
Swift revealed during an Oct. 3 interview on Capital FM that she was excited to learn that an opalite is "actually a man-made opal."
She noted that an opal is the Kansas City Chiefs tight end's birthstone and that she’s always “loved that stone.”

“I thought it was a kind of a cool metaphor that it’s a man-made opal and happiness can also be man-made too," she explained. "So that’s kind of what the song is about: the kind of juxtaposition of those two."
As for Kelce, he told his brother and co-host Jason Kelce that “Opalite” is his favorite song on Swift's new album during an episode of their "New Heights” podcast in August.
“Every time it comes on, I always catch myself,” he said.

title: Neil Patrick Harris and David Burtka on Their Two Favorite Things: Cocktails and Halloween
summary: Neil Patrick Harris and David Burtka open up about their new book "Both Sides of the Glass" and tease what their family is planning for Halloween this year.
story: Neil Patrick Harris loves a good cocktail, and so does his husband, David Burtka — sans the alcohol.

When Burtka decided to embrace sobriety nine years ago, the couple changed how they enjoyed drinks together through a simple work-around: Harris mixed up his favorite cocktails and Burtka did the same without liquor.
“We’ve been together for over 20 years, and I think you have to have a sense of respect for each other in order to maintain a healthy relationship,” Harris tells TODAY.com in a sit-down interview.
In theory, it was a good compromise, but Burtka ultimately realized that his non-alcohol options were largely non-existent, unlike the curated mocktails available today.
“So, it’s like your simple syrup and your grenadine and your pineapple juice and orange juice and there’s your mocktail,” Burtka explains. “It didn’t feel special. I felt like a kid.”

To remedy that, Burtka and Harris, a mixologist in his own right, began experimenting with various recipes, creating personalized versions of their favorite drinks. The result is “Both Sides of the Glass: Paired Cocktails and Mocktails to Toast Any Taste,” a new book that features cocktail and mocktail recipes.

“We think this was a good opportunity to share some recipes that we’ve made and to create some more recipes that balanced and complemented each other so that you could enjoy the same experience whether you were drinking alcohol or not,” Harris says of their collaboration.
Along with its premise of offering both alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages, the book is also unique in that it divides its drink recipes into four distinct categories: Water, fire, air and earth.
In the introduction of the book, Harris and Burtka explain why.
“So much of enjoying a cocktail if filling out the mood — it’s the companion to that rainy afternoon, or the perfect addition to that sexy date night — that we decided to organize it by elements.
“To us, drinks have a mood or a feeling to them, and this felt like the best way for us to think about them,” they pen in the book.
‘I Wanted to Feel Like an Adult’

Among the various concoctions are tried-and-true favorites like the Mai Tai, margarita and old fashioned, as well as quirkier drinks like the Penicillin, a blend of scotch, ginger and honey, and  its non-alcoholic companion, the Antibiotic.
There’s even a Shirley Temple, but it's “for adults” and aptly named the Dirty Shirley.
The refined drinks, says Burtka, help take old-school mocktails to the next level. “I wanted to feel like an adult. I didn’t want to feel like a kid,” he explains.
Both Harris and Burtka agree that of all the various beverages in the book, they’re partial to the negronis.

“If you drink any kind of burnt orange bitter flavor before dinner, it opens up your palate,” says Burtka, a professional chef. “That’s why a lot of people have a negroni spritz — so they can open up the palate, so the food tastes even more delicious.”
I wanted to feel like an adult. I didn’t want to feel like a kid.
David Burtka on "Both Sides of the Glass"

Harris says their decision to make the book was inspired by Zoë Chapin, a friend who proposed the idea after noting that there were cocktail and mocktail books, respectively, but not one that combined both.
“We thought that’s kind of a cool idea,” the “How I Met Your Mother” star says. More than that, he and Burtka realized it was the perfect gift for other people in situations like their own.
“Whether they do drink or not, you don’t want to be disrespectful, so it’s kind of a cool gift,” Harris explains.

As parents to their fraternal 15-year-old twins, Harper and Gideon, the pair says that the mocktails in the book are also great for kids who want to feel included among the adults, despite being too young to drink alcohol.

“You want to sort of share the same experience,” Harris says. “So, if you’re doing a Thanksgiving, you’re having cocktails before, it’s nice for the kids to even enjoy as well, let your kids be special.”
‘Black Magic Margarita’
Included in their collection of cocktails is the Black Magic Marg, one of Harris' signature drinks blended from blackberries and tequila, as well as its non-alcoholic mate, the Black Magic Moment.

The drinks are a nod to the couple's well-known passion for Halloween. Famous for their legendary costumes, Harris, Burtka and their kids have made headlines throughout the years with many of their over-the-top looks.

“We love Halloween and every year we look forward to it,” says Harris. “Unfortunately, it’s tricky. Every year as the kids get older, the dynamic shifts. We love trick-or-treating. Our kids are in high school now. If they go to try and trick-or-treat, everyone at the door is like, “Uh, aren’t you a bit old for this now?” he laughs.

Their Halloween plans will look a bit different this year, though, since Harris is currently appearing on Broadway in “Art,” a comedy co-starring James Corden and Bobby Cannavale, and has a performance on Oct. 31.
Even so, he and Burtka are still cooking up something to celebrate the spooky holiday.

“We have a Halloween costume for Instagram that I think everyone’s agreed on,” Harris teases. “It’s tricky because you have to do a costume that will fit one girl and three boys that will not embarrass the two of them.”
Though they won’t reveal exactly what they’ve settled on, Harris does mention how much thought has gone into it.
“It’s been a lot of overthinking,” he says. “But I think we found something that’s awesome.”

title: Rush Announces 2026 Tour: Here Are the Details
summary: Rush has announced the 2026 “Fifty Something” tour honoring late drummer Neil Peart and the band's music. The tour will feature drummer Anika Nilles.
story: Rush is ready to return to the limelight.

The Rock & Roll Hall of Famers announced Oct. 6 they will headline a tour next year. The “Fifty Something” tour will feature founding members Geddy Lee and Alex Lifeson celebrating the band’s legacy and honoring late drummer Neil Peart, who died in 2020.
The tour marks the first time Lee and Lifeson will have toured together since Rush's “R40 Tour” ended in 2015.
“It’s been over 10 years since Alex and I have performed the music of Rush alongside our fallen bandmate and friend Neil,” Lee said in a statement announcing the tour.

“A lifetime’s worth of songs that we had put our cumulative hearts and souls into writing, recording and playing together onstage. And so, after all that has gone down since that last show, Alex and I have done some serious soul searching and come to the decision that we f------ miss it, and that it’s time for a celebration of 50-something years of Rush music.

“So in 2026, my BFF Lerxst (aka Alex Lifeson) and I are going to hit the road once again to pay tribute to our past and to Neil by performing a vast selection of Rush songs in a handful of cities. No small task, because as we all know Neil was irreplaceable.”

Lee also said they will be joined by drummer Anika Nilles, noting “we could not be more excited to introduce her to our loyal and dedicated Rush fanbase, whom, we know, will give her every chance to live up to that near impossible role.”
Lee said a lot of effort has already gone into putting on a memorable tour.

“Lerxst, Anika and myself, along with many of our longstanding crew members have been hard at work rehearsing and designing the kind of Rush show you’ve grown accustomed to expect from us,” he said. “We dearly hope you will come along and help us celebrate our history together.”
Peart’s widow, Carrie Nuttall-Peart, and daughter, Olivia Peart, are also all in on the tour.

“We are thrilled to support the ‘Fifty Something’ tour, celebrating a band whose music has resonated and inspired fans for generations, and to honor Neil’s extraordinary legacy as both a drummer and lyricist,” they said in a statement.

“As the band enters this new chapter, it promises to be truly unforgettable,” they added. “We are excited to see how their new vision unfolds, and to hear this legendary music played live once again.”
Lee and Lifeson also announced the new tour in a video they shared.
“It feels great to say out loud, finally, that we are going to go on tour,” Lee said.
When Are the Rush Tour Dates in 2026?
Here are the dates of Rush’s “Fifty Something” tour:

How Do I Get Rush Tickets?

title: Could ‘The Life of a Showgirl’ Be Taylor Swift’s Last Album? What She Says About Those Theories
summary: Rest assured, Swifties: Your favorite artist has no desire to leave the life of a showgirl behind anytime soon
story: Rest assured, Swifties: Your favorite artist has no desire to leave the life of a showgirl behind anytime soon.

Since her 12th studio album released Friday, Taylor Swift’s fans have been listening to and talking about it nonstop, attending listening parties, decoding lyrics and looking for Easter eggs. Meanwhile, Swift has been promoting “The Life of a Showgirl” by appearing on radio shows, speaking to hosts eager to know more about the album and her recent engagement to Kansas City Chiefs player Travis Kelce.

During an interview with BBC Radio 2 that dropped early Monday, host Scott Mills brought up one theory he said he’s seen online — that Swift may stop making music as she enters a new chapter in her personal life.
“Taylor, don’t tell me this is your last album,” he said.
“What? No,” Swift replied.
“I just saw some fans going, ‘Well, she’s gonna get married and then she’s gonna have children and this is gonna be the last album,’” the host explained.
“That’s a shockingly offensive thing to say,” Swift said.
Mills agreed, saying, “Absolutely.”
“It’s not why people get married, so that they can quit their job,” she said.
“I think the fans were just panicking,” Mills said.
Swift said she understands, but explained why she has no intention of taking a break from music after getting married.

“I love the person that I am with because he loves what I do, and he loves how much I am fulfilled by making art and making music. That’s the coolest thing about Trav, is, like, he is so passionate about what he does that me being passionate about what I do, it connects us,” she said.
The 35-year-old then said she has no doubt that Kelce will continue to be her No. 1 cheerleader.

“There’s no point in time where he’s going to be like, ‘I’m really upset that you’re still making music. The music thing that I signed up for, that I knew you love, I thought you were going to stop doing that,’” she said.
Mills applauded the couple for how supportive they are of each other, and Swift said it’s one of the things that makes their relationship work.
“It just is the most fun thing in the world to be able to support each other (considering) the sort of polarity of how different our jobs are,” she said.
Swift then explained how, despite the differences in their professions, she and Kelce’s careers are actually quite similar.

“We both do three and a half hour shows to entertain people for three and a half hours in NFL stadiums. When I’m in those stadiums, it’s a dressing room. But when he’s in those exact same stadiums, it’s a locker room. For him, it’s practice. For me, it’s rehearsal. For him, it’s a game. For me, it’s a show. We just call them different things. We both have teams. It’s a very similar thing,” she said.

title: Jennifer Lopez Credits Ben Affleck for Getting Her New Movie Made
summary: Jennifer Lopez said on the TODAY show that ex-husband Ben Affleck is responsible for getting her new movie, "Kiss of the Spider Woman," made.
story: Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck may be divorced, but they’re not letting that interfere with their business relationship.

J.Lo stars in the new movie “Kiss of the Spider Woman.” Her divorce from the Oscar winner was finalized while she was making the film, which boasts her and Affleck as executive producers. She says he is a big reason the project saw the light of day.
“If it wasn’t for Ben, the movie wouldn’t have (gotten) made, and I will always give him that credit,” she said Oct. 6 while appearing on TODAY.
Lopez also said the movie was cathartic for her.
“Things happen. You have to keep going,” she said.

“But, it’s funny. The movie is about escapism. It’s about how movies and art save us in the hardest times of our lives. And doing this project was such a dream come true for me that it really got me through, to kind of survive a moment that was difficult in my personal life, as well.
“So, after that, I took some time off and now we’re back. And I’m really excited for everybody to see this film. It’s a beautiful film about love.”
Craig Melvin then pointed out the movie “may have helped save” Lopez, too.
“It did. It did,” she concurred.

Lopez and Affleck’s love story was one of the most heavily scrutinized public relationships in Hollywood history. The couple got engaged in 2002, but they eventually called off their wedding and split, due in part to the intense media coverage they received.
Lopez would go on to marry and divorce Marc Anthony, with whom she has two kids, and become engaged to Alex Rodriguez, before they broke up.
Affleck married Jennifer Garner, with whom he shares three children, before they divorced.
Affleck and Lopez would reconnect and got engaged in 2022 and married that same year before she filed for divorce in 2024.
“Kiss of the Spider Woman,” which is based on the 1976 novel by Manuel Puig and has already been on Broadway and been made into a 1985 movie with William Hurt and Raul Julia, opens Oct. 10.

title: Peter Bergman Opens Up About the ‘Very Personal’ ‘Y&R’ Episode That Earned Him a Daytime Emmy Nomination
summary: Peter Bergman talks in an interview with TODAY.com about Jack Abbott and his Daytime Emmy-nominated "The Young and the Restless" episode with Melody Thomas Scott.
story: Peter Bergman has been nominated for over 20 Daytime Emmy Awards while playing Jack Abbott on "The Young and The Restless" over the last 36 years, but the actor still feels flattered each time he hears the good news.
“It never gets old. It just doesn’t. There’s something nice about the people in my industry saying, ‘Oh yeah, he’s one of the good ones,'" he tells TODAY.com in a recent interview over the phone.

Bergman, who joined the cast of the daytime soap opera in November 1989, is one of five actors nominated in the lead performance in a daytime drama series category at the 52nd Annual Daytime Emmys, which take place Friday, Oct. 17.
The star is being honored for his performance in a “Y&R” episode from 2024 that follows Jack as he goes to extremes to pull his friend Nikki Newman (Melody Thomas Scott) out of an alcoholic relapse.

When Bergman first heard that only he and Scott would appear in the special episode, he was “dumbstruck,” especially since he didn’t have much advance notice to prepare for the emotionally intense scenes.
“I was a little thrown by it all, I definitely was. And then I read it, and it was pretty clever,” he recalls.

The episode finds Nikki, a former alcoholic, spiraling in a hotel room after a villain named Jordan forced her into a relapse by filling an IV with alcohol to make Nikki dependent on alcohol many years after she became sober.
Jack, who once struggled with an addiction to opioids, has been serving as Nikki’s sponsor. He shows up to convince her to get help, but is met with resistance.

In a last-ditch effort to rattle Nikki out of her relapse, Jack risks his own sobriety to make Nikki realize how far she has fallen. He calls his old drug dealer and gets a pill delivery. Then he ingests the pills.
It’s been a long time since Bergman has had the opportunity to tap into this side of Jack, so he had fun filming the scenes.
“Jack has kind of morphed into the head of the Abbott family and a responsible person. (I thought), 'How many more chances am I going to get to cut loose?'” he says.
Bergman On Jack's True Motivation for Helping Nikki
At first, Bergman didn't think his character was going to go through with taking the pills, but after drinking with Nikki, he thinks Jack felt more uninhibited.

Aside from being Nikki’s sponsor and friend, Jack is also her former husband. Bergman thinks his character saw this as a chance to redeem himself for a tragedy that occurred during their marriage: a miscarriage she suffered after tripping down the stairs while arguing with her former love interest, Victor Newman (Eric Braeden), whom she later reconciled with and is currently married to. Afterward, Nikki turned to alcohol to cope with her pain.

“That was a marvelous story to get to play because Jack was an enabler. He was not the right thing for his wife. And it just got worse and worse and worse," Bergman says, adding that the couple eventually "destroyed" their relationship.
Flash-forward a few years, and Bergman thinks Jack couldn't help but recall why his former wife first became an alcoholic.
"This was Jack’s chance at redemption, to be her sponsor, to really come through for her, to help her through this in a way he could not when it was very important to him and he failed,” he says.
Bergman On the Repercussions of Jack's Actions
Jack risked it all to help Nikki and eventually succeeded since she did get help for her addiction. However, the bold move created a lot of chaos in both Jack's and Nikki’s lives.

“Jack paid such a price for this. His son (Kyle, played by Michael Mealor) lost respect for him. His wife (Diane, played by Susan Walters) questioned his love for her and commitment to their marriage,” Bergman says.
Jack and Victor have been "mortal enemies" for decades, Bergman says, and Victor was furious to hear that Jack put Nikki's life in danger.

“Jack spent the night in a hotel room with a very drunken Nikki and ordered pills and got so intoxicated he completely passed out while Nikki was drunk as a skunk. Who knows what else went on in that hotel room, Victor thinks," Berman says.

"And if he didn’t hate Jack before this, oh my God, this goes so deep. He hates him with a vengeance that is almost immeasurable because of this. So that this 40-year-old rivalry suddenly is not just renewed, it is enhanced by this story, this one show," he continues.
Although Jack's actions were extreme, Bergman says his character truly believed the end justified the means.
"I don't think Jack has the regrets everyone would like him to have because indeed it was successful in jolting her into sobriety," he says.
Bergman On Preparing for the Emotional Episode
Bergman personally connected with the story on a deeper level since he lost a close friend to alcohol addiction nine years ago.

“It was a giant loss for me, so the subject was a very personal one,” he explains. “I always wondered, ‘Could I have helped him? Could I have done more to help him?’ And Jack was not going to have that feeling. ‘Could I have done more to help Nikki?’ There is no limit to what Jack was going to do to help Nikki.”

Production on the set of a soap opera typically moves at lightning speed, meaning stars don’t often get a lot of time to plan their scenes together. However, Bergman and Scott made it a point to run through the dialogue to get a better grasp of the emotional subject matter.
Filming was broken up into two days, and each day, Bergman had to switch gears to film other episodes.
"That’s as much as my memory has been stretched in daytime," he says.
Looking back on the special episode, Bergman can't help but applaud his "amazing" co-star for her "brave, bold, drunken performance."
"Playing drunk is a hard thing, and she was just brilliant," he says.
Bergman On His Emmy Nomination
Bergman was thrilled when he heard he had received a Daytime Emmy nomination, but it was also a bittersweet moment.
“I was disappointed that Melody didn’t get a nomination because she had probably a harder job in that show,” he says.
Bergman was initially hesitant to submit a tape of this particular episode for consideration for a nomination since there's a limit on how long the tape can be.
“You don’t get to show them that much variety in showing one scene from a show. Yes, it’s a long scene, but it’s one scene from a show,” he explains.
Bergman was also concerned about how the audience would view the scene without the context of the rest of the episode.

"Does the audience know this is not normal behavior for Jack? Does the audience stick around long enough while we kind of set it up that he's trying to help her? Are they going to watch the entire thing and see just how far Jack was willing to go?" he says.
In the end, Bergman says he listened to "wiser people" who encouraged him to submit the scene since it was "unlike anything anyone's going to submit."
Looking back on the episode, Bergman says it was "the most challenging thing" he's done on "Y&R."
"It was really up to me to set the pace of every scene, so that was kind of a new challenge and a challenge I liked," he says.

title: 'Girl Dad' Jelly Roll Praises Lainey Wilson as a 'Role Model' at Her Concert: Watch the Video
summary: Jelly Roll spoke about how amazing Lainey Wilson is after she brought him out during her concert at Nashville's Bridgestone Arena on Oct. 2.
story: Jelly Roll has lots of love for the kind of artist Lainey Wilson is.
During her concert at Nashville's Bridgestone Arena on Oct. 2 for her current “Whirlwind World Tour,” Wilson brought the “Need a Favor” singer onto the stage, where he raved about her.
“I want you to know, as a girl dad, what you mean to my family and my daughter and all these little girls in this building, the inspiration,” he said.
“You are the role model us parents were praying for, to encourage these young women to be brave, be bold and share their testimony across the globe. You did that, girl.”
Jelly Roll also praised the “Heart Like a Truck” singer for her contributions to country music.
“You brought the bell-bottoms back in style, girl,” he said, as his voice rose in excitement.
“You made country music cool again,” he said. “A 66-city ‘Whirlwind Tour,’ sounds like the entertainer of the year to me. I love you, Lainey Wilson!”
The crowd howled while Jelly Roll took off his hat and hugged Wilson, who appeared to be moved by his words.

Wilson won entertainer of the year at the 2025 ACM Awards, beating out a field that included Jelly Roll. Wilson is also up for entertainer of the year at the CMA Awards, which she will host live on Nov. 19 at 8 p.m. ET on ABC. It will mark the second consecutive year she will host the show.
Wilson has emerged as one of the preeminent country stars of her time, but it was a long road to make it to the top, spending three years in Nashville in a camper trailer after she first arrived.

“When I first got there in my camper, you know, I didn’t know that it was going to take me another 10 to 11 years to even, like, crack the egg a little bit,” she told Sunday TODAY’s Willie Geist in June 2024.
She said she was determined to make it.
“I think God laid it on my heart a long time ago. I think it was being from a bunch of hardheaded folks,” she said. “You got to be a little bit nuts to want to do this. You do.”

title: Barbie Unveils Ilona Maher Doll to 'Reflect the Build of Many Strong Athletes'
summary: Mattel unveiled a new doll of U.S. Olympian and rugby player Ilona Maher with a muscular sculpt that reflects the "build of many strong athletes."
story: Mattel launched new one-of-a-kind Barbies made in the likeness of four rugby players from across the globe, including U.S. Olympic medalist Ilona Maher.

Mattel announced Team Barbie — Maher, English player Ellie Kildunne, New Zealander Portia Woodman-Wickliffe and French player Nassira Konde — on Oct. 6, encouraging young girls to "own their confidence proudly."

The launch of the four one-of-a-kind dolls comes ahead of International Day of the Girl on Oct. 11. Krista Berger, senior vice president of Barbie, said in a news release that Mattel is "committed to breaking down the barriers — from gender stereotypes to self-doubt — that hold girls back from realizing their limitless potential."

“We all doubt ourselves at times, myself included,” Maher said in the release. “But I am where I am today, because I kept showing up anyway. Even through tough practice days or days I didn’t feel my best, I continued to put in the work, strengthen my skills, and believe in my ability."
The Ilona Maher Barbie doll will be available for purchase in 2026, and features a new muscular sculpt that is "designed to reflect the build of many strong athletes," Mattel said in a news release.
The muscular sculpt has a "straighter, more athletic torso, visibly defined arms, shoulders and legs, plus sculpted core and back muscles," according to Mattel.
Maher said she’s proud of how far she’s come, and that her commitment grew her confidence in herself and her rugby career.

“If sharing my story can inspire other young girls to believe in themselves the way I have, then I’ll have truly made an impact,” she said. “Being part of Team Barbie is about showing girls that confidence isn’t something to shy away from, but something to own. I’m honored to use my platform to empower the next generation to find that spark of confidence within themselves and let it drive them toward unlocking their limitless possibilities.”
Maher, 29, has taken the rugby world by storm, representing the U.S. in the 2020 and 2024 Olympics and winning the bronze medal alongside her teammates in Paris.
The rugby star spoke about her journey while on TODAY With Jenna & Friends on June 3.
"I did what I could at the Olympics, and I think it was amazing to get my sport on the map and to get people a little bit interested in it," Maher said.

"When you think about rugby, you think like, 'Oh, it's a men's sport.' But no, women are killing it ... and I'm so excited that, you know, for a sport that's male dominated, I'm kind of the face of it," she added.
Maher's influence extends beyond the field — she walked the Sports Illustrated runway earlier this year, after landing on the cover of the famed magazine in 2024.

"I love showing my body. I love showing what this body has done for me — I've been to two Olympics now, it does amazing things on the field," she told TODAY's Jenna Bush Hager in June. "It's just perfect for what it does, and so strong."

She added: "I think other girls seeing that and feeling like, 'Oh my gosh, I have the frame of her,' I think it has not only has helped me, and made me feel more confident, I think it helps others too."

Maher also came in second place on Season 33 of “Dancing with the Stars” with her pro partner, Alan Bersten, and she also co-hosts the "House of Maher" podcast with her sisters, Olivia and Adrianna Maher.

title: The Chiefs Play the Jaguars on 'Monday Night Football.' Could Taylor Swift Attend?
summary: Could Taylor Swift be at the Chiefs game Monday? The Kansas City Chiefs visit the Jacksonville Jaguars on "Monday Night Football" in Week 5 of the 2025 NFL season.
story: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce may have enjoyed some downtime together earlier in 2025, but now that the Kansas City Chiefs are heading into Week 5 of the 2025 NFL season — and Swift just released her much-anticipated 12th studio album, "The Life of a Showgirl," on Oct. 3 —  it's safe to say the couple's schedule has gotten busier.
After a bumpy start to the season, the newly revitalized Chiefs (2-2) take on the Jacksonville Jaguars (3-1) in Jacksonville, Florida, on Monday, Oct. 6, the day after Kelce's 36th birthday.
Could Swift, who showed up last week to Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City when the Chiefs beat the Baltimore Ravens, travel to Florida to see her fiancé and his teammates play again?

Swift has a special connection to Florida. She and Kelce hung out there at an NHL game in June. Swift also sings about the Sunshine State's spooky charms on "Florida!!!," the collaboration she recorded with Florence Welch for her 2024 studio album, "The Tortured Poets Department."
Still, Swift is scheduled to appear on NBC's “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” on Oct. 6 and then NBC's “Late Night with Seth Meyers” on Oct. 8 as she rolls out her new album.
Learn more about the Chiefs' upcoming game below.
When Do the Chiefs Play the Jaguars?
The Kansas City Chiefs take on the Jacksonville Jaguars at EverBank Stadium in Jacksonville, Florida, on Monday, Oct. 6.
What Time Do the Chiefs Play the Jaguars?
Kickoff time is scheduled for 8:15 p.m. ET.
Where to Watch the Chiefs-Jaguars Game
Watch the game live on “Monday Night Football” on ABC and ESPN.

title: Keith Powers and Ryan Destiny Announce Engagement: See the Photoshoot
summary: Actors Keith Powers and Ryan Destiny are engaged after rekindling their romance following a split.
story: Actors Keith Powers and Ryan Destiny announced they are headed down the aisle!
The two actors shared their engagement news in a joint Instagram post Oct. 5, featuring a slideshow of glamorous couple photos that showed off their chemistry and her diamond sparkler.

In the pictures, Powers, 33, and Destiny, 30, looked like they stepped straight out of a romantic bridal catalog. The pair posed together while lounging on a couch, eating take out, goofing around and staring deeply into each other’s eyes.
“Engaged to the love of my life,” Powers wrote in the caption.
Celebrity friends celebrated the couple in the comments.
Chloe Bailey wrote, “I love you guys sm.”
“Omg omg omg!!!!!! Congratulations!!!!!!!” Lori Harvey cheered.
Yvette Nicole Brown wrote, in part, “@keithpowers @ryandestiny you KNOW you two have made Auntie Yvette VERY happy with this news!”
“You guys!!!!! These pictures!!!!” Joey King commented and added multiple heart-eye emoji. “Congratulations.”
Naomi Campbell, La La Anthony, Justine Skye, Kyle Pratt and more famous friends also congratulated Powers and Destiny.

“The Perfect Find” actor and the “Star” alum started dating in 2018 after previously meeting at Teen Vogue party in 2015. But, People reported in 2022 that the two decided to call it quits after four years of dating.

Three years later, the two found their way back to each other. Destiny confirmed when speaking to People at the Essence Black Women in Hollywood Awards in February that they had rekindled their relationship.

“I just love him so much and I just appreciate him every step of the way,” she told the magazine. “He’s such a cheerleader for me, as I am for him. It just means everything. We’re just best friends — you know, we’re more than best friends.”
When Powers was interviewed by People while attending the 2025 Cannes Film Festival in May, he also gushed about their relationship.

“I think partnership really works when you really do look at your partner (the way you would look at) siblings, in a way,” he told the outlet. “We could fight. We might not talk to each other for a minute. But we love each other. We come back. You know what I’m saying?”
“And I feel like for me and Ryan … it’s like this is family,” he continued.

Opening up more about the spark between them, Powers added, “It’s just like we’re so locked in and we just get each other’s jokes and it’s just easy. We just flow honestly. And she teaches me a lot. I don’t know if I teach her stuff, but she teaches me so much. She’s made me a better artist, so it’s been great.”

title: Meghan Markle Makes Her Paris Fashion Week Debut in All White. See the Pics
summary: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, stepped out at Paris Fashion Week over the weekend, donning timeless black-and-white looks for a night out.
story: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, stepped out at Paris Fashion Week over the weekend, donning timeless black-and-white looks for a night out.

The former Meghan Markle made her Paris Fashion Week debut Saturday, Oct. 4 dressed in an all-white pant suit with a wrap-around matching shawl. She accompanied the monochrome fabric with a black pointed-toe heel and slicked-back bun.
Meghan attended the Balenciaga show featuring the fashion house's spring and summer 2026 womenswear line.

On Instagram, Meghan shared a video recapping her Parisian excursion, including shots of notable French monuments, such as the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe, her getting glammed up for the fashion show and a screenshot of a 100-day streak on language-learning app Duolingo.
The video also showed Meghan walking out in her white ensemble to photographers, and hugging Balenciaga creative director Pierpaolo Piccioli.
“About last night,” she captioned the video, thanking Piccioli and Balenciaga, adding a French flag and red heart emoji. “I’ve missed you — thanks for the love.”
On her Instagram story, Meghan shared a clip of herself with her feet up during a car ride, showing off her legs and black heels.
Meghan then appeared to have an outfit change, as she was photographed leaving the Balenciaga dinner after the fashion show Saturday night.

Pictured later in the evening, she wore an ankle-length column dress with a partially open back and draping fabric sweeping along her neckline. She paired the look with another pair of black heels and once again sported a slicked-back bun.
Paris Fashion Week 2025 began Monday, Sept. 29 and is set to run through Tuesday, Oct. 7.

title: All About the True Story That Inspired Dwayne Johnson's 'The Smashing Machine'
summary: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson takes on one of his most personal and fitting roles in “The Smashing Machine,” which is based on Mark Kerr's real life. What to know.
story: Warning: Spoilers ahead for “The Smashing Machine”
Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson takes on one of his most personal and fitting roles in “The Smashing Machine.”

The film, directed by Benny Safdie, follows pioneering mixed martial arts and UFC fighter Mark Kerr over a four-year period in his life as he ascended to fame while MMA was relatively on the up and up. The biopic also shines a light on Kerr amid his own struggles with addiction and a toxic relationship.

“The Smashing Machine” is based on a 2002 HBO documentary of the same name. The film, now in theaters, premiered at the Venice Film Festival on Sept. 1, 2025, with people applauding Johnson’s role and physical transformation to become Kerr. Emily Blunt stars as Kerr’s first wife, Dawn Staples.

“Mark was the greatest fighter in the world at one point, but this film is not even really about fighting — it’s a love story,” Johnson said at the festival. “It’s a love story about Mark and Dawn in this relationship, and it’s a love story about Mark and the love that he had for the thing that he did — his struggle with trying to deliver (in the ring), his challenges and his overcoming.”
He adds, “As you know, Mark OD’d twice, and he’s lucky to be alive — and that’s part of why this story is so special.”
Read on to learn more about the true story that inspired “The Smashing Machine.”
The True Story Behind 'The Smashing Machine'
“The Smashing Machine” takes place from 1997 to 2000, chronicling Mark Kerr’s biggest fights while in the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) and in international tournaments in Brazil and Japan.

One of Kerr's first fights was in 1997 in Brazil, which was re-created for the film. In the movie, Johnson’s Kerr is seen coming out of a striking pyramid with smoke, as it happened in real life. The real-life Kerr got a kick out of that re-creation.

“I was in Vancouver for the set and I was laughing with Benny about it going, ‘Alright, who came up with the pyramid?’” Kerr recalled during a Sept. 25 appearance on the “Joe Rogan Experience” podcast. “The door opening with the fog machines?’...But they reproduced it to a T.”

The soft-spoken athlete received his nickname, The Smashing Machine, for his fierce abilities inside the ring and following his success at the World Vale Tudo Championship 3 in Brazil, according to the UFC.
Kerr would go on to make his UFC debut during the tournament of UFC 14: Showdown, which took place on July 27, 1997, in Birmingham, Alabama.
After defeating both of his opponents, Moti Horenstein and Dan Bobish, he won the heavyweight tournament, UFC notes.
In October of that same year, Kerr won his second consecutive UFC heavyweight tournament title during the Collision Course event that took place Oct. 17, 1997.

As the film depicts, following his UFC wins, Kerr headed to Japan to compete in the MMA promotion Pride Fighting Championships. According to the UFC, Kerr won six of his first eight fights in Pride as a heavyweight.
He did have his losses, which are seen in the movie, that also triggered his health struggles. One fight in particular, against Igor Vovchanchyn, ended in a no-contest, which set him over the edge.
"That was the straw that literally set me over the top," Kerr told Johnson in a joint interview for Sports Illustrated.
Amid his success in the ring, his life behind closed doors proved to be quite the opposite.
His Struggles With Addiction and Overdose

As depicted in the film, Kerr struggled with addiction and took painkillers that were prescribed to him by a doctor. He began using opioids regularly to be able to continue fighting and numb the blows in the ring.
In a 2024 interview on the HJR Podcast, Kerr explained when he believes his addiction started.

“The two components that came together are the expectation that I’m supposed to perform at this level regardless,” he said. “And then the training to perform at that level. And when those two came together, it just created a storm where I’m like, I don’t have time.”
He called taking opiates a “shortcut” that helped “mask the pain.”
“It’s gonna allow me to get in the gym, allow me to train, allow me to maintain this expectation that I have of myself and. the Japanese have of me to compete at this level,” Kerr said.
“The Smashing Machine” showed the consequences of his drug use when Dawn found him unresponsive inside their Arizona home after an overdose.
In real life, Kerr overdosed twice, including in 1999. His recovery was also shown in the film after he checked himself into rehab.
In an October 2025 interview with The Ariel Helwani Show, Kerr confirmed that he's been sober for seven years.
A Tumultuous Relationship
Kerr and girlfriend-turned-wife Dawn's relationship also included many highs and lows.
From the start of the film, the couple, who lived in Arizona at the time, often had strained conversations before they eventually fought and got into heated, and at times, destructive arguments.
Whether it's Dawn making the wrong smoothie, Mark not inviting her to go to Japan for his tournaments or both dealing with his addiction recovery, the two pushed each other's buttons.

The film also depicted a the real-life moment when Dawn attempted to kill herself with a gun after Mark told her to leave their home. Kerr confirmed the moment in his HBO documentary, as well as in an interview with Time.com, sharing that Staples also attempted to hurt herself with razors before grabbing the handgun.

“What I was doing at the time was incredibly selfish. Dawn just wanted my love. She wanted to feel important. The only thing important at the time was me fighting, then the second thing that came in importance was the drug and alcohol use,” Kerr said about his and Staples fights. “A lot of that volatility was because of my actions. I look back on it now, she’s a little girl asking to be loved, and I’m just a little boy that doesn’t know how to accept or give it.”
The two would go on to get married, have a son, Bryce, together, before divorcing in 2006.
While on the “Joe Rogan Experience,” Kerr expressed that watching the film was therapeutic for him.

“It was therapy for me... For the first time, I could actually see my part in it,” he said. “Like I could see my part, how f------ hard I was on the people around me, how just singularly driven I was to accomplish something at all cost. And the person that paid it the most was Dawn. She paid a heavy price.”
In another interview with IndieWire, Kerr reflected on his and his ex-wife's relationship.

“It allowed me to see how hard I was on Dawn, and really admit that to myself,” Kerr said. “Fighting is incredibly selfish; it doesn’t leave a lot of space for other people when it comes to emotion and intimacy. Breaking it down to its essence, Dawn was just a little girl who wanted to be loved, and I was just a boy that couldn’t figure out how to love her.”
He expressed that both of them are different people now and their priority in life is their “beautiful 20-year-old son” and “to be the best parents we can to him.”
“When the movie showed at Venice, I couldn’t believe how emotionally impactful it was,” he added. “It was like therapy with a thousand people in the room. It was a beautiful experience.”
Kerr is now married to fitness consultant Franci Alberding and the two started a wellness company called Absolute Wellness.

title: Bad Bunny Fanboys Over 'KPop Demon Hunters' in 'SNL' Sketch Featuring Singing Group
summary: The “Kpop Demon Hunters” phenomenon has officially reached “Saturday Night Live.”Season 51 of the late-night sketch comedy show kicked off Oct.
story: The “Kpop Demon Hunters” phenomenon has officially reached “Saturday Night Live.”
Season 51 of the late-night sketch comedy show kicked off Oct. 4, 2025, with two-time host Bad Bunny and musical guest, Doja Cat.
The episode featured a sketch dedicated to “Kpop Demon Hunters,” which became the Netflix's most-watched animated film and the most popular film, per Tudum.

In the sketch, Sarah Sherman, Chloe Fineman, Bad Bunny and Mikey Day got together for a long overdue reunion. The friend group immediately started to talk about movies that they planned to see, including “One Battle After Another” and “Frankenstein.”
However, Bad Bunny’s interests went in a slightly different direction as he proudly declared, “Yeah, I like ‘Kpop Demon Hunters.’”
“Have you been watching it a bunch with your kids?” Sherman asked, to which Bad Bunny replied, “I don’t have kids.”
Day made a comment about how all of the kids he knows planned to dress up as the characters for Halloween, leaving Bad Bunny to interject, “It’s actually not for kids. It’s for smart adults.”

Fineman tried to change the subject and brought up her experience seeing Lady Gaga over the summer. However, Bad Bunny had tunnel vision on the Netflix hit as he interjected, “You know what music I like? ‘Kpop Demon Hunters.’”
Day made another attempt to move on from the topic, politely telling Bad Bunny that his new obsession was “cool,” but the rapper had a rebuttal of his own.
“Actually, it’s not ‘cool,’ dog,” he said. “In ‘Kpop Demon Hunters,’ songs are not just songs, they are weapons...What else is going to save you from demons, you idiot.”

Bad Bunny continued his impassioned speech about the movie, which caused even more tension at the table. Fineman attempted to diffuse the situation, but the rapper refused to participate in the conversation, turning away from the group with his arms folded across his chest.
While his friends talked about what had transpired over the last few years, Bad Bunny’s internal monologue took center stage.

“Those dumb idiots have no idea. Stupid dummies. I don’t care if they believe me, I have HUNTR/X on my side,” he said in a voiceover, before singers Ejae, Audrey Nuna and Rei Ami — who sang the vocals for the group in “Kpop Demon Hunters” — appeared in a thought bubble and began to sing.
Bad Bunny got called out by the group for ignoring Sherman’s story, though as he pointed out, her misfortune “sounds like the work of a demon.”
“If only there were three gorgeous Korean girls who could protect you, idiot,” he added.
